background: A high rise building is buying two types of furnaces, a new model and an old model to heat its apartments.
constraints: Number of new model furnaces is an integer
Number of old model furnaces is an integer
Number of new model furnaces is non-negative
Number of old model furnaces is non-negative
At most MaxOldProp% of the furnaces can be the old model
At least MinNew new model furnaces should be used
Need to heat at least MinApartments apartments
Have at most MaxEnergy kWh of electricity available
Energy consumed by new model furnaces plus energy consumed by old model furnaces must not exceed MaxEnergy
Heat from new model furnaces plus heat from old model furnaces must be at least MinApartments
objective: Minimize the total number of furnaces purchased
description: A high rise building is buying two types of furnaces, a new model and an old model. A new model furnace can heat \var{HeatNew} apartments and consumes \var{EnergyNew} kWh per day. An old model can heat \var{HeatOld} apartments and consumes \var{EnergyOld} kWh per day. Since the old model is harder to find, at most \var{MaxOldProp} of the furnaces can be the old model and at least \var{MinNew} new model furnaces should be used. If the high rise needs to heat at least \var{MinApartments} apartments and has \var{MaxEnergy} kWh of electricity available, how many of each furnace should be purchased to minimize the total number of furnaces?

parameters.definition: Number of apartments a new model furnace can heat
Daily energy consumption of a new model furnace
Number of apartments an old model furnace can heat
Daily energy consumption of an old model furnace
Maximum proportion of old model furnaces
Minimum number of new model furnaces to be used
Minimum number of apartments to be heated
